problem_statement: Show that the lines \( \vec{r} = (-\hat{i} - 3\hat{j} - 5\hat{k}) + s(3\hat{i} + 5\hat{j} + 7\hat{k}) \) and \( \vec{r} = (2\hat{i} + 4\hat{j} + 6\hat{k}) + t(\hat{i} + 4\hat{j} + 7\hat{k}) \) are coplanar. Also, find the non-parametric vector equation of the plane containing these lines.
overview: To check coplanarity of two lines, we use the vector condition: \((\vec{c} - \vec{a}) \cdot (\vec{b} \times \vec{d}) = 0\). Here, \(\vec{a}, \vec{b}\) correspond to point and direction vector of the first line, and \(\vec{c}, \vec{d}\) correspond to the second line. If satisfied, the lines are coplanar. Then, the plane containing them is given by: \((\vec{r} - \vec{a}) \cdot (\vec{b} \times \vec{d}) = 0\).

step_details.explanation: Identify the position vectors and direction vectors of the two lines.
Compute the cross product \( \vec{b} \times \vec{d} \), which is perpendicular to the plane of the two direction vectors.
step_details.side_comment: $\color{blue}{\text{This gives the normal to the plane containing both directions.}}$

step_details.explanation: Find the vector \( \vec{c} - \vec{a} \), which joins a point on the first line to a point on the second line.
Check the coplanarity condition using the scalar triple product.
step_details.side_comment: $\color{blue}{\text{Since scalar triple product = 0, the two lines lie in the same plane.}}$
